I hate everything about this, including the comments made by both sides in 
this discussion. In my opinion, the problem is that zoos no longer know how 
to define themselves correctly. Zoos should present themselves as places 
where wild animals are safe, protected, and well cared for. At the same 
time, zoos should contrast the lives zoo animals have with the lives 
animals living in the wild animals have. When an animal living in the wild 
is killed, or even dies naturally, it usually suffers first. That is not 
the case in zoos, even in cases like what this zoo has done, which I 
disagree with. But I still think is better than the treatment nature gives 
animals. Finally, I wish zoos that wanted to show presentations like this 
would only do so in cases in which their animals died naturally.﻿

I mostly agree with the PETA lady on the fact that zoos are essentially 
prisons for animals and that its inhumane to kill these animals for food or 
education, I can't get behind that. However I disagree about the education 
that the dissections provide to the viewer ship, though I think it would be 
more humane to only do dissections of animals who died naturally. Of course 
that just leads you to question, is it moral to feed the lions meat from a 
farm like beef or chicken, but immoral to feed them zebra? The immorality 
here doesn't seem to be on what they ate, but how they came about it. If 
that zebra was hunted down by the lions in the wild, I doubt PETA would 
much mind that, let nature take its course. I suppose its more along the 
lines that the zebra doesn't get the chance to run, the chance to live 
another day, its fate is dictated by a cognizant source rather than luck 
and ability.﻿

wrong.
